ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to write a lot of proofs and developed a firm understanding of mathematical analysis.
Really improved my proof-writing and problem-solving ability
I learned how to write strong/clear proofs and got a better understanding of the core concepts of calculus
Improved my mathematical literacy, proof-writing skills, and ability to evaluate, create, and perfect more advanced and detailed mathematical arguments.
I built upon my reasoning skills and proof writing skills. I feel more comfortable with approaching mathematical concepts of the sort and found it fun.

I learned about the theory of numbers and calculus! We started with a quick introduction to proofs and logic, and then we learned about topics like sequences, series, functions, convergence, continuity and differentiability/integrability.
Overview of real analysis topics building from natural numbers to real numbers to sequences to functions to continuity to differentiation to integration. Topology and finiteness also covered.

I learned how mathematics was built up. Starting with Peano's axioms, I learned the construction of the naturals, followed by the integers, followed by the rationals, and then the reals. I then learned how we rigorously prove the foundational results that led to differentiation and integration.
Improved my proof writing skills. Learned to read advanced mathematics. Can understand and enhanced deeper concepts in calculus.

MATH 255 lays down the foundation for all future math classes. You essentially build the real numbers and related operations (including calculus) from the ground up. Along the way, I learned new proof techniques. All in all, an essential beginning to proof-based math (though quite an advanced beginning course).
Improved proof-writing skills and knowledge of calculus foundations
You learn everything you would expect in an analysis course: number systems, sequences and series, topology, continuity, differentiation, and integration
I gained a far deeper and more rigorous understanding of calculus from first principles. The course helped change the way I view problem solving and logical methods.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found the content to be crucial for a Mathematics major and believe the course serves this purpose well. I think the course was a bit fast-paced and not enough support was given for a class of this difficulty level. There could have been more office hours.

The course had great teaching and fantastic ULAs, a high but manageable workload, and very fair exams. It was rewarding to take and I really felt like I was learning a lot each week. A weakness is definitely the pace of the course-- it was extremely fast, and each lecture felt a little bit like high speed time travel. I understand there was a lot of content to cover but the course would definitely be improved by slowing the pace slightly. Also would have appreciated better feedback on homework submissions (exam feedback was usually good though)

Long, hard homeworks, which were helpful but strictly graded. The slow build-up, with heavy early emphasis on basic logical foundations of real analysis, proved tremendously helpful. Lectures were fast-paced but mostly accessible, and professor was highly available to students throughout the semester. A fair and transparent grading structure that encouraged cooperation between students, not competition. Lectures didn't always correspond to particular textbook chapters, since we used multiple books with varying levels of detail.
The pacing was great, the homeworks were fun, and I loved Francos lecture style.

Strengths: Thorough overview of real analysis.
Weaknesses: sometimes lectures went too quick and were difficult to follow. There was not a primary textbook used to clarify information and follow along.

Weaknesses:
- Terrible terrible terrible organization. Office hours were constantly cancelled the same day of the office hour. It wasn't clear which problems came in the exams or when and where the office hours will be held. This really made the experience much harder.
- The ULAs did not have good answers to the problems. In many cases they did not know what to answer to certain questions.

It can be improved by having a lecturer as the professor and by adding a GOOD teaching fellow.

MATH 255 is marketed as an "intro" proofs class, though this iteration of this course was quite dense. I think more practice with proof techniques and the language of proofs would've been helpful. Also, there was just SO much material. You're essentially building calculus from the ground up, but I think the course could've benefitted from less content - it is supposed to be a gentle introduction to proofs, but I feel like most people already came up with some working knowledge of proof-based math. I struggled quite a bit, since 255 was my first proof-based course.

I also had mixed feelings about the structure of the exams, where each question was a proof we had seen before. Though we knew exactly what to expect, it felt more like a memorization challenge rather than an application of the material. There were A LOT of proofs that were fair game - I'd estimate we'd learn about 15-20 new proofs a week. I think the course gave an advantage to those who had seen this before and, given that this is an introductory course, I would've appreciated a more even playing field.
Generally clear lectures and well-organized. Exams are very fair.

The content is more difficult to grasp than linear algebra, but having a good textbook(s) and following it closely makes a huge difference if you find a specific proof or concept difficult to follow in class.
The pacing of the course felt a bit off with some topics such as elementary logic getting too much of a focus and others like topology and integration feeling a bit rushed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student only if it is required for their major and they are already comfortable with writing proofs and thinking mathematically. Otherwise this course is way too fast-paced and really difficult to follow at times.

Yes if it is relevant to your course of study. This is the class I was most scared to take this semester but I actually sort of enjoyed it and definitely learned a lot. Don't be scared! You can do it!
Yes, your mathematical maturity will improve tremendously and you will get a much better understanding of what the math major will be like.
Yes! Even if I werent a math major I would love a class like this.
It is an intense overview of real analysis.

If you are a math major, then yes, since this is a core part of mathematics. However, I don't know if I would say the same for non-math majors. This course isn't as "fun" as other proof-based classes such as linear algebra, and at times, the rigor of proving everything (even the stuff that seems like second-hand nature) can be tedious and a bit tiresome. Nonetheless, if you are interested in this and are willing to put in the work, this class is great.

Mixed opinions. Franco is a FANTASTIC lecturer - kind, engaging. Truly the highlight of the course. I showed up to every lecture; in part, because he didn't record the lectures, but more so that he clearly loves math and wants to share his joy of math. Office hours with him were always a pleasure; he would break down the steps of each proof and made everything click. As someone who had minimal experience with proof-based math, he truly made sure that I learned the material.

That being said, MATH 255 is a LOT of work. I struggled on each PSET and had to go to devote 2-3 hours each week to go to office hours, in addition to the 2-3 hours it took me to actually write the PSET. Midterms and finals were fair, though. I'd say only take this class if you have people to work together with - it can be very isolating.
Yes
Yes, analysis is beautiful, and you will walk away feeling like you've learned something valuable
Yes, not only is it crucial for an understanding of theoretical math but it also exposes students to a methodology of analytical thinking that carries over into different fields.
